The financial services industry is experiencing rapid technological changes, affecting product and service implementation and increasing the need for investment in new technologies.
Challenges in implementing new technology could result in operational difficulties, competitive disadvantages, and financial repercussions.
The company remains open to pursuing acquisitions to grow the business and addresses potential risks associated with such actions.
Failure to keep pace with technological advancements may adversely impact business operations and financial condition.

The images show the exterior and interior of what appears to be the Bridgewater Bank building. The exterior shot features modern architecture with large glass windows and signage. The interior features vibrant artistic murals painted on the walls and stairwell area. The most prominent artwork shows a large, colorful bird (appears to be an oriole) in flight rendered in bright yellow/orange and blue tones against a dramatic blue background. The murals appear to be part of the building's interior design, creating an energetic and modern corporate environment.

elements.title: Dividend Policy and Stock Repurchase Program Details

data.value: The payment of cash dividends on common stock is contingent on several factors, including earnings and regulatory guidelines.
The ability to declare and pay dividends is influenced by federal regulations and the Federal Reserve's guidelines.

data.key: Impact of Future Earnings on Dividends
data.value: Future ability to pay dividends may be adversely affected if capital requirements are not met.
Future issuances of common stock may dilute existing shareholders and negatively impact stock price.
Holders of debt and preferred stock have priority over common stockholders in liquidation events.
As of December 31, 2022, $80.0 million of subordinated debentures outstanding.
As of December 31, 2022, $69.0 million of preferred stock outstanding.
On August 17, 2022, a new stock repurchase program was approved to repurchase up to $25.0 million of common stock.
The new repurchase program will expire on August 16, 2024.
The new program replaced a previous $40.0 million program, of which approximately $1.6 million remained.
There is no guarantee that the stock repurchase program will be fully implemented or enhance shareholder value.

elements.title: Management’s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting

data.value: Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure: None.

data.key: Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures
data.value: The Company’s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company’s disclosure controls and procedures as of December 31, 2022.
The Company’s disclosure controls and procedures were effective to ensure that the information required to be disclosed is recorded, processed, summarized and reported in accordance with SEC’s rules.
Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
Management assessed the Company’s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2022.
Assessment was based on criteria set forth by COSO in Internal Control-Integrated Framework, 2013.
The CEO and CFO assert that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2022.

data.value: Simple quality loan products for commercial clients, including commercial lending, loans secured by nonfarm and nonresidential properties, multifamily residential properties, owner occupied single family properties, construction loans, land development loans, and industrial loans.
A variety of deposit products targeted at commercial clients including remote deposit and cash management products, as well as traditional retail deposit products.
Focus primarily on the Twin Cities MSA with over 80% of real estate loan balances secured by properties located in this market.
Robust growth due to strengthening brand, service model, M&A-related disruptions, and expansion of lending and business service teams.

elements.title: GAAP Reconciliation and Management Explanation of Non-GAAP Financial Measures

data.value: Defined as net interest income plus total noninterest income (excluding all gains and losses on sales of assets) minus total non-interest expense, excluding the amortization of tax credit investments and debt prepayment fees.
The ratio of net interest income (on a fully tax-equivalent basis), reduced by loan fees and PPP interest and fees, divided by interest earning assets, excluding average PPP loans.

Defined as noninterest expense less the amortization of intangibles divided by operating revenue, which is equal to net interest income plus noninterest income excluding gains and losses on sales of assets.
The efficiency ratio adjusted to exclude amortization of tax credit investments and debt prepayment fees from noninterest expense.

data.key: Adjusted Noninterest expense to average assets
data.value: The ratio of noninterest expense adjusted to exclude the amortization of tax credit investments and debt prepayment fees, divided by average assets.
Shareholders’ equity reduced by preferred stock, goodwill and other intangible assets.

data.key: Tangible common equity to tangible assets
data.value: The ratio of tangible common equity divided by total assets reduced by goodwill and other intangible assets.
Tangible common shareholders’ equity divided by total common voting and non-voting shares outstanding.

data.key: Return on average tangible common equity
data.value: The ratio of net income available to common shareholders, divided by average tangible common equity.

data.key: Adjusted Diluted Earnings per Common Share
data.value: Net income available to common shareholders excluding the impact of debt prepayment fees divided by diluted weighted average common shares outstanding.

This table presents a comprehensive income statement across three years (2020-2022). Net income shows steady growth from $27,194 in 2020 to $53,392 in 2022. However, in 2022, there was a significant unrealized loss on available-for-sale securities (-$56,914), partially offset by gains on cash flow hedges ($20,430). Despite strong net income in 2022, the large other comprehensive loss resulted in lower comprehensive income of $26,444 compared to $48,114 in 2021. The table demonstrates considerable volatility in other comprehensive income components, particularly in 2022.

data.value: The core principle requires an entity to recognize revenue to depict the transfer of goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration it expects to be entitled to receive.
Substantially all of the Company’s revenue is generated from financial instruments, including interest income related to loans and investment securities.

This table presents the components of comprehensive income for the years 2020-2022, showing before-tax amounts, tax effects, and net-of-tax figures. The main components are unrealized gains/losses on available-for-sale securities and cash flow hedges. Notable trends include a significant unrealized loss on available-for-sale securities in 2022 (-$41,265k net of tax) compared to smaller losses in 2021 and gains in 2020. The overall comprehensive income showed a loss of $26,948k in 2022, compared to gains of $2,427k in 2021 and mixed results in 2020.

The Bank cannot declare or pay a cash dividend unless it has a surplus of at least 20% of its capital.
Dividends can be paid if the surplus reaches 50% of the Bank’s capital and does not reduce capital below MDOC requirements.
Payment of dividends is contingent on cumulative preferred stock dividends being paid in full.
The FDIC and MDOC may restrict dividend payments if deemed unsafe or unsound.
The Bank exceeded its capital requirements under applicable guidelines as of December 31, 2022.
Dividend payments must maintain compliance with capital adequacy guidelines.
The Company has not historically declared or paid dividends on its common stock.
The Company does not intend to declare or pay dividends on its common stock in the foreseeable future.
Future earnings will be retained to support operations and finance growth.
Future determinations regarding dividends will depend on financial condition, liquidity, operations results, capital needs, tax considerations, and market conditions.
The Company is not obligated to pay dividends and is subject to restrictions.

elements.title: Risk Factors Regarding Future Use of Reference Rates and Loans

data.value: Developments and uncertainty related to the future use and availability of reference rates such as the expected discontinuation of the London Interbank Offered Rate.
Imposition of governmental policies impacting product values, potential impairment to goodwill, outcome of litigation, and changes to tax laws.
Interest rate risk and fluctuations in securities portfolio values.

elements.title: Credit Risk and Environmental Liabilities in Loan Portfolio

data.value: The credit risk associated with real estate loan portfolio is exposed to fluctuations in market value and adverse changes affecting real estate values.
Hazardous substances on pledged properties may impose remediation costs, impacting property value and financial stability.
The bank's operations are concentrated in the Twin Cities MSA, increasing vulnerability to local economic downturns.
Risk management practices are essential to handling credit risk and preventing defaults and charge-offs.
The allowance for loan losses may be insufficient to absorb potential losses in the loan portfolio.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Commercial Loans

data.value: Commercial loans are sensitive to the overall business climate and economy.
Cumulative effects of rising inflation, labor shortages, supply chain constraints, and a recession may impact collectability of loans.
Collateral like inventory and equipment may depreciate and fluctuate in value.
Larger average size of commercial loans increases potential for adverse impact on financial results.
Construction loans may suffer from inaccuracies in cost and valuation estimates, leading to possible significant losses.
High concentration of loans to a small number of borrowers increases credit risk.
Small to midsize businesses may have fewer resources, impairing their loan repayment ability.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Economic Conditions and Loan Portfolio Management

data.value: The business is vulnerable to economic downturns, needing substantial additional capital to expand or compete, with potential volatility in operating results impacting loan repayment.
The success often depends on a small group of individuals; their loss could materially impact the business.
Increased seasoning of the loan portfolio could elevate the risks of credit defaults.
A significant portion of the loan portfolio is of recent origin, delaying signs of credit deterioration or defaults.
Nonperforming loans as of December 31, 2022, represent $639,000, or 0.02% of the loan portfolio.
Nonperforming assets adversely affect net interest income, and their resolution requires significant management effort.
Liquidity is essential; inability to meet obligations may arise from difficulty liquidating assets or obtaining funding.

elements.title: Risks Related to Reputation and Security Breaches

data.value: General macroeconomic factors could have a material adverse impact on business, financial condition, and growth prospects. Reputation is critical to success, and damage could undermine client confidence.
Bank is susceptible to fraudulent activity and information security breaches, which may result in financial losses and damage to reputation.
There is a rise in cyber-attacks targeting financial services, resulting in information security breaches that may expose client data and financial information.
Secure maintenance and transmission of confidential information are essential to protect against fraud and security breaches.
Dependence on third party partners for technology and information security increases vulnerability to breaches and associated financial losses.

elements.title: Risks Associated with Acquisitions and New Business Ventures

data.value: Acquiring new lines of business or products presents risks due to lack of experience.
Failure to manage risks could adversely affect financial condition and growth.
The pandemic continues to disrupt business and economic conditions.
Increased competition from both banks and non-banks.
Rapid technological changes require adaptation to meet client needs.
Competitors' new products may affect client loyalty.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to LIBOR Transition and Commercial Real Estate Lending Concentration

data.value: Concerns regarding the transition from LIBOR to alternative rates include potential disputes, litigation, and the need for changes in risk management practices.
Federal regulators recommend heightened risk management practices for institutions with high concentrations in commercial real estate lending.
The risk management framework may not be effective in mitigating various types of risks, which could lead to unexpected losses.
Management must exercise judgment in selecting accounting policies that may result in materially different financial reporting.
